Â 

20. â€œWhen he has investigated him and has seen that he is purified from states based on delusion, then he places faith in him; filled with faith he visits him and pays respect to him; having paid respect to him, he gives ear; when he gives ear, he hears the Dhamma; having heard the Dhamma, he memorises it and examines the meaning of the teachings he has memorised; when he examines their meaning, he gains a reflective acceptance of those teachings; when he has gained a reflective acceptance of those teachings, zeal springs up; when zeal has sprung up, he applies his will; having applied his will, he scrutinises;889 having scrutinised, he strives;890 resolutely striving, he realises with the body the supreme truth and sees it by penetrating it with wisdom.891 In this way, BhaÌ„radvaÌ„ja, there is the discovery of truth; in this way one discovers truth; in this way we describe the discovery of truth. But as yet there is no final arrival at truth.â€892

Â 

21. â€œIn that way, Master Gotama, there is the discovery of truth; in that way one discovers truth; in that way we recognise the discovery of truth. But in what way, Master Gotama, is there the final arrival at truth? In what way does one finally arrive at truth? We ask Master Gotama about the final arrival at truth.â€ \[174\] â€œThe final arrival at truth, BhaÌ„radvaÌ„ja, lies in the repetition, development, and cultivation of those same things. In this way, BhaÌ„radvaÌ„ja, there is the final arrival at truth; in this way one finally arrives at truth; in this way we describe the final arrival at truth.â€

Â 

22. â€œIn that way, Master Gotama, there is the final arrival at truth; in that way one finally arrives at truth; in that way we recognise the final arrival at truth. But what, Master Gotama, is most helpful for the final arrival at truth? We ask Master Gotama about the thing most helpful for the final arrival at truth.â€ â€œStriving is most helpful for the final arrival at truth, BhaÌ„radvaÌ„ja. If one does not strive, one will not finally arrive at truth; but because one strives, one does finally arrive at truth. That is why striving is most helpful for the final arrival at truth.â€

Â 

23. â€œBut what, Master Gotama, is most helpful for striving? We ask Master Gotama about the thing most helpful for striving.â€

Â 

â€œScrutiny is most helpful for striving, BhaÌ„radvaÌ„ja. If one does not scrutinise, one will not strive; but because one scrutinises, one strives. That is why scrutiny is most helpful for striving.â€

Â 

24. â€œBut what, Master Gotama, is most helpful for scrutiny? We ask Master Gotama about the thing most helpful for scrutiny.â€

Â 

â€œApplication of the will is most helpful for scrutiny, BhaÌ„radvaÌ„ja. If one does not apply oneâ€™s will, one will not scrutinise; but because one applies oneâ€™s will, one scrutinises. That is why application of the will is most helpful for scrutiny.â€

Â 

25. â€œBut what, Master Gotama, is most helpful for application of the will? We ask Master Gotama about the thing most helpful for application of the will.â€ â€œZeal is most helpful for application of the will, BhaÌ„radvaÌ„ja. If

Â 

one does not arouse zeal, one will not apply oneâ€™s will; but because one arouses zeal, one applies oneâ€™s will. That is why zeal is most helpful for application of the will.â€

Â 

26. â€œBut what, Master Gotama, is most helpful for zeal? \[175\] We ask Master Gotama about the thing most helpful for zeal.â€

Â 

â€œA reflective acceptance of the teachings is most helpful for zeal, BhaÌ„radvaÌ„ja. If one does not gain a reflective acceptance of the teachings, zeal will not spring up; but because one gains a reflective acceptance of the teachings, zeal springs up. Â 

27. â€œBut what, Master Gotama, is most helpful for a reflective acceptance of the teachings? We ask Master Gotama about the thing most helpful for a reflective acceptance of the teachings.â€

Â 

â€œExamination of the meaning is most helpful for a reflective acceptance of the teachings, BhaÌ„radvaÌ„ja. If one does not examine their meaning, one will not gain a reflective acceptance of the teachings; but because one examines their meaning, one gains a reflective acceptance of the teachings. That is why examination of the meaning is most helpful for a reflective acceptance of the teachings.â€

Â 

28. â€œBut what, Master Gotama, is most helpful for examination of the meaning? We ask Master Gotama about the thing most helpful for examination of meaning.â€

Â 

â€œMemorising the teachings is most helpful for examining the meaning, BhaÌ„radvaÌ„ja. If one does not memorise a teaching, one will not examine its meaning; but because one memorises a teaching, one examines its meaning.â€

Â 

29. â€œBut what, Master Gotama, is most helpful for memorising the teachings? We ask Master Gotama about the thing most helpful for memorising the teachings.â€

Â 

â€œHearing the Dhamma is most helpful for memorising the teachings, BhaÌ„radvaÌ„ja. If one does not hear the Dhamma, one will not memorise the teachings; but because one hears the Dhamma, one memorises the teachings. That is why hearing the Dhamma is most helpful for memorising the teachings.â€

Â 

30. â€œBut what, Master Gotama, is most helpful for hearing the Dhamma? We ask Master Gotama about the thing most helpful for hearing the Dhamma.â€

â€œGiving ear is most helpful for hearing the Dhamma, BhaÌ„radvaÌ„ja. \[176\] If one does not give ear, one will not hear the Dhamma; but because one gives ear, one hears the Dhamma. That is why giving ear is most helpful for hearing the Dhamma.â€

34. â€œWe asked Master Gotama about the preservation of truth, and Master Gotama answered about the preservation of truth; we approve of and accept that answer, and so we are satisfied. 35. â€œMagnificent, Master Gotama\! Magnificent, Master Gotama\!...\(*as Sutta 91, Â§37*\)...From today let Master Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone to him for refuge for life.â€

## ***EsukaÌ„riÌ„ Sutta* **

Â 

**To EsukaÌ„riÌ„**

Â 

1. THUS HAVE I HEARD. On one occasion the Blessed One was living at SaÌ„vatthiÌ„ in Jetaâ€™s Grove, AnaÌ„thapinÌ£dÌ£ikaâ€™s Park.

Â 

2. Then the brahmin EsukaÌ„riÌ„ went to the Blessed One and exchanged greetings with him. When this courteous and amiable talk was finished, he sat down at one side and said:

Â 

3. â€œMaster Gotama, the brahmins prescribe four levels of service. They prescribe the level of service towards a brahmin, the level of service towards a noble, the level of service towards a merchant, and the level of service towards a worker. Therein, Master Gotama, the brahmins prescribe this as the level of service towards a brahmin: a brahmin may serve a brahmin, a noble may serve a brahmin, a merchant may serve a brahmin, and a worker may serve a brahmin. That is the level of service towards a brahmin \[178\] that the brahmins prescribe. Master Gotama, the brahmins prescribe this as the level of service towards a noble: a noble may serve a noble, a merchant may serve a noble, and a worker may serve a noble. That is the level of service towards a noble that the brahmins prescribe. Master Gotama, the brahmins prescribe this as the level of service towards a merchant: a merchant may serve a merchant and a worker may serve a merchant. That is the level of service towards a merchant that the brahmins prescribe. Master Gotama, the brahmins prescribe this as the level of service towards a worker: only a worker may serve a worker; for who else could serve a worker? That is the level of service towards a worker that the brahmins prescribe. What does Master Gotama say about this?â€

Â 

4. â€œWell, brahmin, has all the world authorised the brahmins to prescribe these four levels of service?â€â€”â€œNo, Master Gotama.â€â€”â€œSuppose, brahmin, they were to force a cut of meat upon a poor, penniless, destitute man and tell him: â€˜Good man, you must eat this meat and pay for itâ€™; so too, without the consent of those \[other\] recluses and brahmins, the brahmins nevertheless prescribe those four levels of service.

Â 

5. â€œI do not say, brahmin, that all are to be served, nor do I say that none are to be served. For if, when serving someone, one becomes worse and not better because of that service, then I say that he should not be served. And if, when serving someone, one becomes better and not worse because of that service, then I say that he should be served.

Â 

6. â€œIf they were to ask a noble thus: â€˜Which of these should you serveâ€”one in whose service you become worse and not better when serving him, or one in whose service you become better and not worse when serving him: \[179\] answering rightly, a noble would answer thus: â€˜I should not serve the one in whose service I become worse and not better when serving him; I should serve the one in whose service I become better and not worse when serving him.â€™

Â 

â€œIf they were to ask a brahminâ€¦to ask a merchantâ€¦to ask a workerâ€¦answering rightly, a worker would answer thus: â€˜I should not serve the one in whose service I become worse and not better when serving him; I should serve the one in whose service I become better and not worse when serving him.â€™

Â 

7. â€œI do not say, brahmin, that one is better because one is from an aristocratic family, nor do I say that one is worse because one is from an aristocratic family. I do not say that one is better because one is of great beauty, nor do I say that one is worse because one is of great beauty. I do not say that one is better because one is of great wealth, nor do I say that one is worse because one is of great wealth.

Â 

8. â€œFor here, brahmin, one from an aristocratic family may kill living beings, take what is not given, misconduct himself in sensual pleasures, speak falsely, speak maliciously, speak harshly, gossip, be covetous, have a mind of ill will, and hold wrong view. Therefore I do not say that one is better because one is from an aristocratic family. But also, brahmin, one from an aristocratic family may abstain from killing living beings, from taking what is not given, from misconduct in sensual pleasures, from false speech, from malicious speech, from harsh speech, and from gossip, and he may be uncovetous, have a mind without ill will, and hold right view. Â 

â€œHere, brahmin, one of great beautyâ€¦one of great wealth may kill living beingsâ€¦and hold wrong view. Therefore I do not say that one is better because one is of great beautyâ€¦of great wealth. But also, brahmin, one of great beautyâ€¦of great wealth may abstain from killing living beingsâ€¦and hold right view. Therefore \[180\] I do not say that one is worse because one is of great beautyâ€¦of great wealth.

Â 

9. â€œI do not say, brahmin, that all are to be served, nor do I say that none are to be served. For if, when serving someone, oneâ€™s faith, virtue, learning, generosity, and wisdom increase in his service, then I say that he should be served.â€

Â 

10. When this was said, the brahmin EsukaÌ„riÌ„ said to the Blessed One: â€œMaster Gotama, the brahmins prescribe four types of wealth. They prescribe the wealth of a brahmin, the wealth of a noble, the wealth of a merchant, and the wealth of a worker.

Â 

â€œTherein, Master Gotama, the brahmins prescribe this as the wealth of a brahminâ€”wandering for alms;894 a brahmin who spurns his own wealth, wandering for alms, abuses his duty like a guard who takes what has not been given. That is the wealth of a brahmin which the brahmins prescribe. Master Gotama, the brahmins prescribe this as the wealth of a nobleâ€”the bow and quiver; a noble who spurns his own wealth, the bow and quiver, abuses his duty like a guard who takes what has not been given. That is the wealth of a noble which the brahmins prescribe. Master Gotama, the brahmins prescribe this as the wealth of a merchantâ€”farming and cattle-breeding;895 a merchant who spurns his own wealth, farming and cattle-breeding, abuses his duty like a guard who takes what has not been given. That is the wealth of a merchant which the brahmins prescribe. **To Subha**

1. THUS HAVE I HEARD. On one occasion the Blessed One was living at SaÌ„vatthiÌ„ in Jetaâ€™s Grove, AnaÌ„thapinÌ£dÌ£ikaâ€™s Park.

2. Now on that occasion the brahmin student Subha, Todeyyaâ€™s son, was staying at the residence of a certain householder in SaÌ„vatthiÌ„ for some business or other.908 Then the brahmin student Subha, Todeyyaâ€™s son, asked the householder in whose residence he was staying: â€œHouseholder, I have heard that SaÌ„vatthiÌ„ is not devoid of arahants. 3. Then, having assented to the householder, the brahmin student Subha, Todeyyaâ€™s son, went to the Blessed One and exchanged greetings with him. When this courteous and amiable talk was finished, he sat down at one side and asked the Blessed One:

4. â€œMaster Gotama, the brahmins say this: â€˜The householder is accomplishing the true way, the Dhamma that is wholesome. The one gone forth \[into homelessness\] is not accomplishing the true way, the Dhamma that is wholesome.â€™ What does Master Gotama say about this?â€

Â 

â€œStudent, I speak about this after making an analysis;909 I do not speak about this one-sidedly. I do not praise the wrong way of practice on the part either of a householder or one gone forth; for whether it be a householder or one gone forth, one who has entered on the wrong way of practice, by reason of his wrong way of practice, is not accomplishing the true way, the Dhamma that is wholesome. I praise the right way of practice on the part either of a householder or one gone forth; for whether it be a householder or one gone forth, one who has entered on the right way of practice, by reason of his right way of practice, is accomplishing the true way, the Dhamma that is wholesome.â€

5. â€œMaster Gotama, the brahmins say this: â€˜Since the work of the household life involves a great deal of activity, great functions, great engagements, and great undertakings, it is of great fruit. Â 

â€œAgain, student, I speak about this after making an analysis; I do not speak about this one-sidedly. There is work involving a great deal of activity, great functions, great engagements, and great undertakings, which, when it fails, is of small fruit. There is work involving a great deal of activity, great functions, great engagements, and great undertakings, which, when it succeeds, is of great fruit. There is work involving a small amount of activity, small functions, small engagements, and small undertakings, which, when it fails, is of small fruit. There is work involving a small amount of activity, small functions, small engagements, and small undertakings, which, when it succeeds, is of great fruit.

23. â€œAnd how is exertion fruitful, bhikkhus, how is striving fruitful? ## **\(THE IMPERTURBABLE\)**

3. â€œTherein, bhikkhus, a noble disciple considers thus: â€˜Sensual pleasures here and now and sensual pleasures in lives to comeâ€¦constitute an obstruction to a noble disciple in training here. 5. â€œAgain, bhikkhus, a noble disciple considers thus:1013 â€˜Sensual pleasures here and now and sensual pleasures in lives to come, sensual perceptions here and now and sensual perceptions in lives to come, material forms here and now and material forms in lives to come, perceptions of forms here and now and perceptions of forms in lives to comeâ€”both alike are impermanent. 6. â€œAgain, bhikkhus, a noble disciple considers thus:1014 â€˜Sensual pleasures here and now and sensual pleasures in lives to come, sensual perceptions here and now and sensual perceptions in lives to come, material forms here and now and material forms in lives to come, perceptions of forms here and now and perceptions of forms in lives to come, and perceptions of the imperturbableâ€”all are perceptions. ## **\(THE BASE OF NEITHER-PERCEPTION-NOR-NON-PERCEPTION\)**

Â 

9. â€œAgain, bhikkhus, a noble disciple considers thus: â€˜Sensual pleasures here and now and sensual pleasures in lives to come, sensual perceptions here and now and sensual perceptions in lives to come, material forms here and now and material forms in lives to come, perceptions of forms here and now and perceptions of forms in lives to come, perceptions of the imperturbable, and perceptions of the base of nothingnessâ€”all are perceptions. Where these perceptions cease without remainder, that is the peaceful, that is the sublime, namely, the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception. â€™ When he practises in this way and frequently abides thus, his mind acquires confidence in this base. Once there is full confidence, he either attains to the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception now or else he resolves \[upon it\] with wisdom. On the dissolution of the body, after death, it is possible that the evolving consciousness may pass on \[to rebirth\] in the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception. This, bhikkhus, is declared to be the way directed to the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.â€

## ***SevitabbaÌ„sevitabba Sutta* **

## **\(FIRST EXPOSITION\)**

Â 

3. â€œBhikkhus,1069 bodily conduct is of two kinds, I say: to be cultivated and not to be cultivated. And bodily conduct is either the one or the other.1070 Verbal conduct is of two kinds, I say: to be cultivated and not to be cultivated. And verbal conduct is either the one or the other. Mental conduct is of two kinds, I say: to be cultivated and not to be cultivated. And mental conduct is either the one or the other. Inclination of mind is of two kinds, I say: to be cultivated and not to be cultivated. And inclination of mind is either the one or the other. \[46\] The acquisition of perception is of two kinds, I say: to be cultivated and not to be cultivated. And the acquisition of perception is either the one or the other. The acquisition of view is of two kinds, I say: to be cultivated and not to be cultivated. And the acquisition of view is either the one or the other. The acquisition of individuality is of two kinds, I say: to be cultivated and not to be cultivated. And the acquisition of individuality is either the one or the other.â€

Â 





## **\(FIRST ELABORATION\)**

Â 

4. When this was said, the venerable SaÌ„riputta said to the Blessed One: â€œVenerable sir, I understand the detailed meaning of the Blessed Oneâ€™s utterance, which he has spoken in brief without expounding the detailed meaning, to be thus:

Â 

5. â€œâ€˜Bhikkhus, bodily conduct is of two kinds, I say: to be cultivated and not to be cultivated. And bodily conduct is either the one or the other.â€™ So it was said by the Blessed One. And with reference to what was this said?

Â 

â€œVenerable sir, such bodily conduct as causes unwholesome states to increase and wholesome states to diminish in one who cultivates it should not be cultivated. But such bodily conduct as causes unwholesome states to diminish and wholesome states to increase in one who cultivates it should be cultivated.

Â 

â€œAnd what kind of bodily conduct causes unwholesome states to increase and wholesome states to diminish in one who cultivates it? Here someone kills living beings; he is murderous, bloody-handed, given to blows and violence, merciless to living beings. He takes what is not given; he takes by way of theft the wealth and property of others in the village or in the forest. He misconducts himself in sensual pleasures; he has intercourse with such women as are protected by their mother, father, mother and father, brother, sister, or relatives, who have a husband, who are protected by law, and even with those who are garlanded in token of betrothal. Such bodily conduct \[47\] causes unwholesome states to increase and wholesome states to diminish in one who cultivates it.

Â 

â€œAnd what kind of bodily conduct causes unwholesome states to diminish and wholesome states to increase in one who cultivates it? Here someone, abandoning the killing of living beings, abstains from killing living beings; with rod and weapon laid aside, gently and kindly, he abides compassionate to all living beings. Abandoning the taking of what is not given, he abstains from taking what is not given; he does not take by way of theft the wealth and property of others in the village or in the forest. Abandoning misconduct in sensual pleasures, he abstains from misconduct in sensual pleasures; he does not have intercourse with such women as are protected by their mother, father, mother and father, brother, sister, or relatives, who have a husband, who are protected by law, or with those who are garlanded in token of betrothal. â€œSo it was with reference to this that it was said by the Blessed One: â€˜Bhikkhus, bodily conduct is of two kinds, I say: to be cultivated and not to be cultivated. And bodily conduct is either the one or the other.â€™

He speaks maliciously; he repeats elsewhere what he has heard here in order to divide \[those people\] from these, or he repeats to these people what he has heard elsewhere in order to divide \[these people\] from those; thus he is one who divides those who are united, a creator of divisions, who enjoys discord, rejoices in discord, delights in discord, a speaker of words that create discord. He speaks harshly; he utters such words as are rough, hard, hurtful to others, offensive to others, bordering on anger, unconducive to concentration. He is a gossip; he speaks at the wrong time, speaks what is not fact, speaks what is useless, speaks contrary to the Dhamma and the Discipline; at the wrong time he speaks such words as are worthless, unreasonable, immoderate, and unbeneficial. â€œAnd what kind of verbal conduct causes unwholesome states to diminish and wholesome states to increase in one who cultivates it? 1. THUS HAVE I HEARD. On one occasion the Blessed One was living at SaÌ„vatthÄ« in Jetaâ€™s Grove, AnaÌ„thapiá¹‡á¸ikaâ€™s Park. There he addressed the bhikkhus thus: â€œBhikkhus.â€â€”â€œVenerable sir,â€ they replied. The Blessed One said this:

2. â€œBhikkhus, whatever fears arise, all arise because of the fool, not because of the wise man; whatever troubles arise, all arise because of the fool, not because of the wise man; whatever calamities arise, all arise because of the fool, not because of the wise man. No fear comes from the wise man, no trouble comes from the wise man, no calamity comes from the wise man. ## **\(THE ELEMENTS\)**

Â 

4. â€œBut, venerable sir, in what way can a bhikkhu be called skilled in the elements?â€

Â 

â€œThere are, AÌ„nanda, these eighteen elements: the eye element, the form element, the eye-consciousness element; the ear element, the sound element, the ear-consciousness element; the nose element, the odour element, the nose-consciousness element; the tongue element, the flavour element, the tongue-consciousness element; the body element, the tangible element, the body-consciousness element; the mind element, the mind-object element, the mind-consciousness element. Â 

5. â€œBut, venerable sir, might there be another way in which a bhikkhu can be called skilled in the elements?â€

Â 

â€œThere might be, AÌ„nanda. There are, AÌ„nanda, these six elements: the earth element, the water element, the fire element, the air element, the space element, and the consciousness element. When he knows and sees these six elements, a bhikkhu can be called skilled in the elements.â€

Â 

6. â€œBut, venerable sir, might there be another way in which a bhikkhu can be called skilled in the elements?â€

## **\(DEPENDENT ORIGINATION\)**

Â 

11. â€œBut, venerable sir, in what way can a bhikkhu be called skilled in dependent origination?â€1083

Â 

â€œHere, AÌ„nanda, a bhikkhu knows thus: â€˜When this exists, that comes to be; with the arising of this, that arises. When this does not exist, that does not come to be; with the cessation of this, that ceases. That is, with ignorance as condition, formations \[come to be\]; with formations as condition, consciousness; with consciousness as condition, mentality-materiality; with mentality-materiality as condition, the sixfold base; with the sixfold base as condition, contact; with contact as condition, feeling; with feeling as condition, craving; with craving as condition, clinging; with clinging as condition, \[64\] being; with being as condition, birth; with birth as condition, ageing and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, grief, and despair come to be. Such is the origin of this whole mass of suffering.

Â 

â€œâ€˜But with the remainderless fading away and cessation of ignorance comes cessation of formations; with the cessation of formations, cessation of consciousness; with the cessation of consciousness, cessation of mentality-materiality; with the cessation of mentality-materiality, cessation of the sixfold base; with the cessation of the sixfold base, cessation of contact; with the cessation of contact, cessation of feeling; with the cessation of feeling, cessation of craving; with the cessation of craving, cessation of clinging; with the cessation of clinging, cessation of being; with the cessation of being, cessation of birth; with the cessation of birth, ageing and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, grief, and despair cease. 7. On that occasionâ€”the Uposatha day of the fifteenth, the full-moon night of the KomudÄ« full moon of the fourth monthâ€”the Blessed One was seated in the open surrounded by the Sangha of bhikkhus. Then, surveying the silent Sangha of bhikkhus, he addressed them thus:

## **\(MINDFULNESS OF BREATHING\)**

Â 

15. â€œBhikkhus, when mindfulness of breathing is developed and cultivated, it is of great fruit and great benefit. When mindfulness of breathing is developed and cultivated, it fulfils the four foundations of mindfulness. When the four foundations of mindfulness are developed and cultivated, they fulfil the seven enlightenment factors. When the seven enlightenment factors are developed and cultivated, they fulfil true knowledge and deliverance.

Â 

16. â€œAnd how, bhikkhus, is mindfulness of breathing developed and cultivated, so that it is of great fruit and great benefit?

Â 

17. â€œHere a bhikkhu, gone to the forest or to the root of a tree or to an empty hut, sits down; having folded his legs crosswise, set his body erect, and established mindfulness in front of him, ever mindful he breathes in, mindful he breathes out.

Â 

18. â€œBreathing in long, he understands:1117 â€˜I breathe in longâ€™; or breathing out long, he understands: â€˜I breathe out long.â€™ Breathing in short, he understands: â€˜I breathe in shortâ€™; or breathing out short, he understands: â€˜I breathe out short.â€™ He trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe in experiencing the whole body \[of breath\]â€™; he trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe out experiencing the whole body \[of breath\].â€™ He trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe in tranquillising the bodily formationâ€™; he trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe out tranquillising the bodily formation.â€™

Â 

19. â€œHe trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe in experiencing raptureâ€™; he trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe out experiencing rapture.â€™1118 He trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe in experiencing pleasureâ€™; \[83\] he trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe out experiencing pleasure.â€™ He trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe in experiencing the mental formationâ€™; he trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe out experiencing the mental formation. â€™ He trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe in tranquillising the mental formationâ€™; he trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe out tranquillising the mental formation.â€™1119

Â 

20. â€œHe trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe in experiencing the mindâ€™; he trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe out experiencing the mind.â€™ He trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe in gladdening the mindâ€™; he trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe out gladdening the mind.â€™ He trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe in concentrating the mindâ€™; he trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe out concentrating the mind.â€™ He trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe in liberating the mindâ€™; he trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe out liberating the mind.â€™1120

Â 

21. â€œHe trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe in contemplating impermanenceâ€™; he trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe out contemplating impermanence. â€™ He trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe in contemplating fading awayâ€™; he trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe out contemplating fading away.â€™ He trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe in contemplating cessationâ€™; he trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe out contemplating cessation.â€™ He trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe in contemplating relinquishmentâ€™; he trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe out contemplating relinquishment. â€™1121

Â 

22. â€œBhikkhus, that is how mindfulness of breathing is developed and cultivated, so that it is of great fruit and great benefit.

## **\(FULFILMENT OF THE FOUR FOUNDATIONS OF MINDFULNESS\)**

Â 

23. â€œAnd how, bhikkhus, does mindfulness of breathing, developed and cultivated, fulfil the four foundations of mindfulness?

Â 

24. â€œBhikkhus, on whatever occasion a bhikkhu, breathing in long, understands: â€˜I breathe in long,â€™ or breathing out long, understands: â€˜I breathe out longâ€™; breathing in short, understands: â€˜I breathe in short,â€™ or breathing out short, understands: â€˜I breathe out shortâ€™; trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe in experiencing the whole body \[of breath\]â€™; trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe out experiencing the whole body \[of breath\]â€™; trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe in tranquillising the bodily formationâ€™; trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe out tranquillising the bodily formationâ€™â€”on that occasion a bhikkhu abides contemplating the body as a body, ardent, fully aware, and mindful, having put away covetousness and grief for the world. I say that this is a certain body among the bodies, namely, in-breathing and out-breathing.1122 That is why on that occasion a bhikkhu abides contemplating the body as a body, ardent, fully aware, and mindful, having put away covetousness and grief for the world.

Â 

25. â€œBhikkhus, on whatever occasion \[84\] a bhikkhu trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe in experiencing raptureâ€™; trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe out experiencing raptureâ€™; trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe in experiencing pleasureâ€™; trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe out experiencing pleasureâ€™; trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe in experiencing the mental formationâ€™; trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe out experiencing the mental formationâ€™; trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe in tranquillising the mental formationâ€™; trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe out tranquillising the mental formationâ€™â€”on that occasion a bhikkhu abides contemplating feelings as feelings, ardent, fully aware, and mindful, having put away covetousness and grief for the world. I say that this is a certain feeling among the feelings, namely, giving close attention to in-breathing and out-breathing.1123 That is why on that occasion a bhikkhu abides contemplating feelings as feelings, ardent, fully aware, and mindful, having put away covetousness and grief for the world.

Â 

26. â€œBhikkhus, on whatever occasion a bhikkhu trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe in experiencing the mindâ€™; trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe out experiencing the mindâ€™; trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe in gladdening the mindâ€™; trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe out gladdening the mindâ€™; trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe in concentrating the mindâ€™; trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe out concentrating the mindâ€™; trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe in liberating the mindâ€™; trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe out liberating the mindâ€™â€”on that occasion a bhikkhu abides contemplating mind as mind, ardent, fully aware, and mindful, having put away covetousness and grief for the world. I do not say that there is the development of mindfulness of breathing for one who is forgetful, who is not fully aware. That is why on that occasion a bhikkhu abides contemplating mind as mind, ardent, fully aware, and mindful, having put away covetousness and grief for the world.1124

Â 

27. â€œBhikkhus, on whatever occasion a bhikkhu trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe in contemplating impermanenceâ€™; trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe out contemplating impermanenceâ€™; trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe in contemplating fading awayâ€™; trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe out contemplating fading awayâ€™; trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe in contemplating cessationâ€™; trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe out contemplating cessationâ€™; trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe in contemplating relinquishmentâ€™; trains thus: â€˜I shall breathe out contemplating relinquishmentâ€™â€”on that occasion a bhikkhu abides contemplating mind-objects as mind-objects, ardent, fully aware, and mindful, having put away covetousness and grief for the world. Having seen with wisdom the abandoning of covetousness and grief, \[85\] he closely looks on with equanimity.1125 That is why on that occasion a bhikkhu abides contemplating mind-objects as mind-objects, ardent, fully aware, and mindful, having put away covetousness and grief for the world.

Â 

28. â€œBhikkhus, that is how mindfulness of breathing, developed and cultivated, fulfils the four foundations of mindfulness.

Â 





## **\(FULFILMENT OF THE SEVEN ENLIGHTENMENT FACTORS\)**

Â 

29. â€œAnd how, bhikkhus, do the four foundations of mindfulness, developed and cultivated, fulfil the seven enlightenment factors?

Â 

30. â€œBhikkhus, on whatever occasion a bhikkhu abides contemplating the body as a body, ardent, fully aware, and mindful, having put away covetousness and grief for the worldâ€”on that occasion unremitting mindfulness is established in him. On whatever occasion unremitting mindfulness is established in a bhikkhuâ€”on that occasion the mindfulness enlightenment factor is aroused in him, and he develops it, and by development, it comes to fulfilment in him.

Â 

31. â€œAbiding thus mindful, he investigates and examines that state with wisdom and embarks upon a full inquiry into it. On whatever occasion, abiding thus mindful, a bhikkhu investigates and examines that state with wisdom and embarks upon a full inquiry into itâ€”on that occasion the investigation-of-states enlightenment factor is aroused in him, and he develops it, and by development it comes to fulfilment in him.

Â 

32. â€œIn one who investigates and examines that state with wisdom and embarks upon a full inquiry into it, tireless energy is aroused. On whatever occasion tireless energy is aroused in a bhikkhu who investigates and examines that state with wisdom and embarks upon a full inquiry into itâ€”on that occasion the energy enlightenment factor is aroused in him, and he develops it, and by development it comes to fulfilment in him.

Â 

33. â€œIn one who has aroused energy, unworldly rapture arises. On whatever occasion unworldly rapture arises in a bhikkhu who has aroused energyâ€”\[86\] on that occasion the rapture enlightenment factor is aroused in him, and he develops it, and by development it comes to fulfilment in him.

Â 

34. â€œIn one who is rapturous, the body and the mind become tranquil. On whatever occasion the body and the mind become tranquil in a bhikkhu who is rapturousâ€”on that occasion the tranquillity enlightenment factor is aroused in him, and he develops it, and by development it comes to fulfilment in him.

Â 

35. â€œIn one whose body is tranquil and who feels pleasure, the mind becomes concentrated. On whatever occasion the mind becomes concentrated in a bhikkhu whose body is tranquil and who feels pleasureâ€”on that occasion the concentration enlightenment factor is aroused in him, and he develops it, and by development it comes to fulfilment in him.

Â 

36. â€œHe closely looks on with equanimity at the mind thus concentrated. On whatever occasion a bhikkhu closely looks on with equanimity at the mind thus concentratedâ€”on that occasion the equanimity enlightenment factor is aroused in him, and he develops it, and by development it comes to fulfilment in him.

Â 

37. â€œBhikkhus, on whatever occasion a bhikkhu abides contemplating feelings as feelings, ardent, fully aware, and mindful, having put away covetousness and grief for the worldâ€¦\(*repeat as at Â§Â§30â€“36*\)...the equanimity enlightenment factor is aroused in him, and he develops it, and by development it comes to fulfilment in him.

Â 

38. â€œBhikkhus, on whatever occasion a bhikkhu abides contemplating mind as mind, ardent, fully aware, and mindful, having put away covetousness and grief for the world...\(*repeat as at Â§Â§30â€“36*\)...the equanimity enlightenment factor is aroused in him, and he develops it, and by development it comes to fulfilment in him.

Â 

39. â€œBhikkhus, on whatever occasion a bhikkhu abides contemplating mind-objects as mind-objects, ardent, fully aware, and mindful, having put away covetousness and grief for the world...\(*repeat as at Â§Â§30â€“36*\)...\[87\]...the equanimity enlightenment factor is aroused in him, and he develops it, and by development it comes to fulfilment in him.

Â 

40. â€œBhikkhus, that is how the four foundations of mindfulness, developed and cultivated, fulfil the seven enlightenment factors.1126 \[88\]

## **\(FULFILMENT OF TRUE KNOWLEDGE AND DELIVERANCE\)**

Â 

41. â€œAnd how, bhikkhus, do the seven enlightenment factors, developed and cultivated, fulfil true knowledge and deliverance?

42. â€œHere, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu develops the mindfulness enlightenment factor, which is supported by seclusion, dispassion, and cessation, and ripens in relinquishment.1127 He develops the investigation-of-states enlightenment factorâ€¦the energy enlightenment factorâ€¦the rapture enlightenment factorâ€¦the tranquillity enlightenment factorâ€¦the concentration enlightenment factorâ€¦the equanimity enlightenment factor, which is supported by seclusion, dispassion, and cessation, and ripens in relinquishment.

43. â€œBhikkhus, that is how the seven enlightenment factors, developed and cultivated, fulfil true knowledge and deliverance.â€1128

â€œHere, venerable sir, we were sitting in the assembly hall, where we had met together on returning from our almsround, after our meal, when this discussion arose among us: â€˜It is wonderful, friends, it is marvellous, how it has been said by the Blessed One who knows and sees, accomplished and fully enlightened, that mindfulness of the body, when developed and cultivated, is of great fruit and great benefit.â€™ This was our discussion, venerable sir, that was interrupted when the Blessed One arrived.â€

3. â€œAnd how, bhikkhus, is mindfulness of the body developed and cultivated so that it is of great fruit and great benefit?

## **\(MINDFULNESS OF BREATHING\)**

4. â€œHere a bhikkhu,1129 gone to the forest or to the root of a tree or to an empty hut, sits down; having folded his legs crosswise, set his body erect, and established mindfulness in front of him, ever mindful he breathes in, mindful he breathes out. ## **\(THE FOUR POSTURES\)**

Â 

5. â€œAgain, bhikkhus, when walking, a bhikkhu understands: â€˜I am walkingâ€™; when standing, he understands: â€˜I am standingâ€™; when sitting, he understands: â€˜I am sittingâ€™; when lying down, he understands: â€˜I am lying downâ€™; or he understands accordingly however his body is disposed. ## **\(FULL AWARENESS\)**

Â 

6. â€œAgain, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu is one who acts in full awareness when going forward and returning; who acts in full awareness when looking ahead and looking away; who acts in full awareness when flexing and extending his limbs; who acts in full awareness when wearing his robes and carrying his outer robe and bowl; who acts in full awareness when eating, drinking, consuming food, and tasting; who acts in full awareness when defecating or urinating; who acts in full awareness when walking, standing, sitting, falling asleep, waking up, talking, and keeping silent. ## **\(FOULNESSâ€”THE BODILY PARTS\)**

7. â€œAgain, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu reviews this same body up from the soles of the feet and down from the top of the hair, bounded by skin, as full of many kinds of impurity thus: â€˜In this body there are head-hairs, body-hairs, nails, teeth, skin, flesh, sinews, bones, bone-marrow, kidneys, heart, liver, diaphragm, spleen, lungs, intestines, mesentery, contents of the stomach, feces, bile, phlegm, pus, blood, sweat, fat, tears, grease, spittle, snot, oil of the joints, and urine.â€™ Just as though there were a bag with an opening at both ends full of many sorts of grain, such as hill rice, red rice, beans, peas, millet, and white rice, and a man with good eyes were to open it and review it thus: â€˜This is hill rice, this is red rice, these are beans, these are peas, this is millet, this is white riceâ€™; so too, a bhikkhu reviews this same body as full of many kinds of impurity thus: â€˜In this body there are headhairsâ€¦and urine.â€™ As he abides thus diligent, ardent, and resolute, his memories and intentions based on the household life are abandonedâ€¦That too is how a bhikkhu develops mindfulness of the body. \[91\]

Â 





## **\(ELEMENTS\)**

Â 

8. â€œAgain, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu reviews this same body, however it is placed, however disposed, as consisting of elements thus: â€˜In this body there are the earth element, the water element, the fire element, and the air element.â€™ Just as though a skilled butcher or his apprentice had killed a cow and were seated at the crossroads with it cut up into pieces; so too, a bhikkhu reviews this same body however it is placed, however disposed, as consisting of elements thus: â€˜In this body there are the earth element, the water element, the fire element, and the air element.â€™ As he abides thus diligent, ardent, and resolute, his memories and intentions connected with the household life are abandonedâ€¦That too is how a bhikkhu develops mindfulness of the body.

## **\(THE NINE CHARNEL GROUND CONTEMPLATIONS\)**

Â 

9. â€œAgain, bhikkhus, as though he were to see a corpse thrown aside in a charnel ground, one, two, or three days dead, bloated, livid, and oozing matter, a bhikkhu compares this same body with it thus: â€˜This body too is of the same nature, it will be like that, it is not exempt from that fate.â€™ As he abides thus diligentâ€¦ That too is how a bhikkhu develops mindfulness of the body.

Â 

10. â€œAgain, as though he were to see a corpse thrown aside in a charnel ground, being devoured by crows, hawks, vultures, dogs, jackals, or various kinds of worms, a bhikkhu compares this same body with it thus: â€˜This body too is of the same nature, it will be like that, it is not exempt from that fate.â€™ As he abides thus diligentâ€¦That too is how a bhikkhu develops mindfulness of the body. \[92\]

Â 

11â€“14. â€œAgain, as though he were to see a corpse thrown aside in a charnel ground, a skeleton with flesh and blood, held together with sinewsâ€¦a fleshless skeleton smeared with blood, held together with sinews...a skeleton without flesh and blood, held together with sinewsâ€¦disconnected bones scattered in all directionsâ€”here a hand-bone, there a foot-bone, here a shin-bone, there a thigh-bone, here a hip-bone, there a back-bone, here a rib-bone, there a breast-bone, here an arm-bone, there a shoulder-bone, here a neck-bone, there a jaw-bone, here a tooth, there the skullâ€”a bhikkhu compares this same body with it thus: â€˜This body too is of the same nature, it will be like that, it is not exempt from that fate.â€™ As he abides thus diligentâ€¦That too is how a bhikkhu develops mindfulness of the body.

Â 

15â€“17. â€œAgain, as though he were to see a corpse thrown aside in a charnel ground, bones bleached white, the colour of shells...bones heaped up...bones more than a year old, rotted and crumbled to dust, a bhikkhu compares this same body with it thus: â€˜This body too is of the same nature, it will be like that, it is not exempt from that fate.â€™ As he abides thus diligentâ€¦That too is how a bhikkhu develops mindfulness of the body.

Â 





## **\(THE JHÌ„NAS\)**

Â 

18. â€œAgain, bhikkhus, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unwholesome states, a bhikkhu enters upon and abides in the first jhaÌ„na, which is accompanied by applied and sustained thought, with rapture and pleasure born of seclusion. He makes the rapture and pleasure born of seclusion drench, steep, fill, and pervade this body, so that there is no part of his whole body unpervaded by the rapture and pleasure born of seclusion. Just as a skilled bath man or a bath manâ€™s apprentice 1130 heaps bath powder in a metal basin and, sprinkling it gradually with water, kneads it till the moisture wets his ball of bath powder, soaks it and pervades it inside and out, yet the ball itself does not ooze; so too, a bhikkhu makes the rapture and pleasure born of seclusion \[93\] drench, steep, fill, and pervade this body, so that there is no part of his whole body unpervaded by the rapture and pleasure born of seclusion. As he abides thus diligentâ€¦That too is how a bhikkhu develops mindfulness of the body.

Â 

19. â€œAgain, bhikkhus, with the stilling of applied and sustained thought, a bhikkhu enters upon and abides in the second jhaÌ„na, which has self-confidence and singleness of mind without applied and sustained thought, with rapture and pleasure born of concentration. He makes the rapture and pleasure born of concentration drench, steep, fill, and pervade this body, so that there is no part of his whole body unpervaded by the rapture and pleasure born of concentration. Just as though there were a lake whose waters welled up from below and it had no inflow from east, west, north, or south, and would not be replenished from time to time by showers of rain, then the cool fount of water welling up in the lake would make the cool water drench, steep, fill, and pervade the lake, so that there would be no part of the whole lake unpervaded by cool water; so too, a bhikkhu makes the rapture and pleasure born of concentration drench, steep, fill, and pervade this body, so that there is no part of his whole body unpervaded by the rapture and pleasure born of concentration. ## **\(BENEFITS OF MINDFULNESS OF THE BODY\)**

Â 

32. â€œBhikkhus, when mindfulness of the body has been repeatedly practised, developed, cultivated, used as a vehicle, used as a basis, established, consolidated, and well undertaken, these ten benefits may be expected. What ten?

Â 

33. \(i\) â€œOne becomes a conqueror of discontent and delight, and discontent does not conquer oneself; one abides overcoming discontent whenever it arises.

Â 

34. \(ii\) â€œOne becomes a conqueror of fear and dread, and fear and dread do not conquer oneself; one abides overcoming fear and dread whenever they arise.

Â 

35. \(iii\) â€œOne bears cold and heat, hunger and thirst, and contact with gadflies, mosquitoes, wind, the sun, and creeping things; one endures ill-spoken, unwelcome words and arisen bodily feelings that are painful, racking, sharp, piercing, disagreeable, distressing, and menacing to life.

Â 

36. \(iv\) â€œOne obtains at will, without trouble or difficulty, the four jhaÌ„nas that constitute the higher mind and \[98\] provide a pleasant abiding here and now.

Â 

37. \(v\) â€œOne wields the various kinds of supernormal powerâ€¦ \(*as Sutta 108, Â§18*\)...one wields bodily mastery even as far as the Brahma-world.

Â 

38. \(vi\) â€œWith the divine ear element, which is purified and surpasses the human, one hears both kinds of sounds, the divine and the human, those that are far as well as near.

Â 

39. \(vii\) â€œOne understands the minds of other beings, of other persons, having encompassed them with oneâ€™s own mind. One understands a mind affected by lust as affected by lustâ€¦\(*as Sutta 108, Â§20*\)...an unliberated mind as unliberated.

Â 

40. \(viii\) â€œOne recollects oneâ€™s manifold past lives, that is, \[99\] one birth, two births...\(*as Sutta 51, Â§24*\)...Thus with their aspects and particulars one recollects oneâ€™s manifold past lives.

Â 

41. \(ix\) â€œWith the divine eye, which is purified and surpasses the human, one sees beings passing away and reappearing, inferior and superior, fair and ugly, fortunate and unfortunate, and one understands how beings pass on according to their actions.

Â 

42. \(x\) â€œBy realising for oneself with direct knowledge, one here and now enters upon and abides in the deliverance of mind and deliverance by wisdom that are taintless with the destruction of the taints.

Â 

43. â€œBhikkhus, when mindfulness of the body has been repeatedly practised, developed, cultivated, used as a vehicle, used as a basis, established, consolidated, and well undertaken, these ten benefits may be expected.â€

Â 

That is what the Blessed One said. The bhikkhus were satisfied and delighted in the Blessed Oneâ€™s words.

â€œSurely, venerable sir, we are living in concord, with mutual appreciation, without disputing, blending like milk and water, viewing each other with kindly eyes.â€

â€œBut, Anuruddha, how do you live thus?â€

Â 

12. â€œVenerable sir, as to that, I think thus: â€˜It is a gain for me, it is a great gain for me that I am living with such companions in the holy life.â€™ I maintain bodily acts of loving-kindness towards these venerable ones both openly and privately; I maintain verbal acts of loving-kindness towards them both openly and privately; I maintain mental acts of loving-kindness towards them both openly and privately. 13. â€œGood, good, Anuruddha. I hope that you all abide diligent, ardent, and resolute.â€ \[157\]

14. â€œVenerable sir, as to that, whichever of us returns first from the village with almsfood prepares the seats, sets out the water for drinking and for washing, and puts the refuse bucket in its place. 15. â€œGood, good, Anuruddha. But while you abide thus diligent, ardent, and resolute, have you attained any superhuman states, a distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones, a comfortable abiding?â€

16. â€œYou should discover the cause for that,1190 Anuruddha. Before my enlightenment, while I was still only an unenlightened Bodhisatta, I too perceived both light and a vision of forms. 17. â€œAs, Anuruddha, I was abiding diligent, ardent, and resolute, I perceived both light and a vision of forms. Soon afterward the light and the vision of forms disappeared. 18. â€œAs, Anuruddha, I was abiding diligentâ€¦I considered thus: â€˜Sloth and torpor arose in me, and because of sloth and torpor my concentration fell away; when my concentration fell away, the light and the vision of forms disappeared. 20. â€œAs, Anuruddha, I was abiding diligentâ€¦I considered thus: â€˜Elation arose in me, and because of elation my concentration fell away; when my concentration fell away, the light and the vision of forms disappeared.â€™ Suppose a man seeking one entrance to a hidden treasure came all at once upon five entrances to a hidden treasure;1191 then elation would arise in him because of that. 21. â€œAs, Anuruddha, I was abiding diligentâ€¦I considered thus: â€˜Inertia arose in me, and because of inertia my concentration fell away; when my concentration fell away, the light and the vision of forms disappeared. 22. â€œAs, Anuruddha, I was abiding diligentâ€¦I considered thus: â€˜Excess of energy arose in me, and because of excess of energy my concentration fell away; when my concentration fell away, the light and the vision of forms disappeared.â€™ Suppose a man were to grip a quail tightly with both hands; it would die then and there. 24. â€œAs, Anuruddha, I was abiding diligentâ€¦I considered thus: â€˜Longing arose in me, and because of that longing my concentration fell away; when my concentration fell away, the light and the vision of forms disappeared. 25. â€œAs, Anuruddha, I was abiding diligentâ€¦I considered thus: â€˜Perception of diversity arose in me,1192 and because of perception of diversity my concentration fell away; when my concentration fell away, the light and the vision of forms disappeared. **Fools and Wise Men**

Â 

\[163\] 1. THUS HAVE I HEARD. On one occasion the Blessed One was living at SÌ„ÄvatthÄ« in Jetaâ€™s Grove, AnaÌ„thapiá¹‡á¸ikaâ€™s Park. There he addressed the bhikkhus thus: â€œBhikkhus.â€â€”â€œVenerable sir,â€ they replied. The Blessed One said this:

## **\(THE FOOL\)**

Â 

2. â€œBhikkhus, there are these three characteristics of a fool, signs of a fool, attributes of a fool. What three? Here a fool is one who thinks bad thoughts, speaks bad words, and does bad deeds. If a fool were not so, how would the wise know him thus: â€˜This person is a fool, an untrue manâ€™? But because a fool is one who thinks bad thoughts, speaks bad words, and does bad deeds, the wise know him thus: â€˜This person is a fool, an untrue man.â€™

Â 

3. â€œA fool feels pain and grief here and now in three ways. If a fool is seated in an assembly or along a street or in a square and people there are discussing certain pertinent and relevant matters, then, if the fool is one who kills living beings, takes what is not given, misconducts himself in sensual pleasures, speaks falsehood, and indulges in wine, liquor, and intoxicants, which are the basis of negligence, he thinks: â€˜These people are discussing certain pertinent and relevant matters; these things are found in me, and I am seen engaging in those things.â€™ This is the first kind of pain and grief that a fool feels here and now.

Â 

4. â€œAgain, when a robber culprit is caught, a fool sees kings having many kinds of torture inflicted on him:1198 \[164\] having him flogged with whips, beaten with canes, beaten with clubs; having his hands cut off, his feet cut off, his hands and feet cut off; his ears cut off, his nose cut off, his ears and nose cut off; having him subjected to the â€˜porridge pot,â€™ to the â€˜polished-shell shave,â€™ to the â€˜RaÌ„huâ€™s mouth,â€™ to the â€˜fiery wreath,â€™ to the â€˜flaming hand,â€™ to the â€˜blades of grass,â€™ to the â€˜bark dress,â€™ to the â€˜antelope,â€™ to the â€˜meat hooks,â€™ to the â€˜coins,â€™ to the â€˜lye pickling, â€™ to the â€˜pivoting pin,â€™ to the â€˜rolled-up palliasseâ€™; and having him splashed with boiling oil, and having him thrown to be devoured by dogs, and having him impaled alive on stakes, and having his head cut off with a sword. Then the fool thinks thus: â€˜Because of such evil actions as those, when a robber culprit is caught, kings have many kinds of tortures inflicted on him: they have him flogged with whipsâ€¦and have his head cut off with a sword. Those things are found in me, and I am seen engaging in those things.â€™ This is the second kind of pain and grief that a fool feels here and now.

Â 

5. â€œAgain, when a fool is on his chair or on his bed or resting on the ground, then the evil actions that he did in the pastâ€”his bodily, verbal, and mental misconductâ€”cover him, overspread him, and envelop him. Just as the shadow of a great mountain peak in the evening covers, overspreads, and envelops the earth, so too, when a fool is on his chair or on his bed or resting on the ground, \[165\] then the evil actions that he did in the pastâ€”his bodily, verbal, and mental misconductâ€”cover him, overspread him, and envelop him. Then the fool thinks: â€˜I have not done what is good, I have not done what is wholesome, I have not made myself a shelter from anguish. I have done what is evil, I have done what is cruel, I have done what is wicked. When I pass away, I shall go to the destination of those who have not done what is goodâ€¦who have done what is wicked.â€™ He sorrows, grieves, and laments, he weeps beating his breast and becomes distraught. This is the third kind of pain and grief that a fool feels here and now.

Â 

6. â€œA fool who has given himself over to misconduct of body, speech, and mind, on the dissolution of the body, after death, reappears in a state of deprivation, in an unhappy destination, even in hell.

## **\(HELL\)**

Â 

7. â€œWere it rightly speaking to be said of anything: â€˜That is utterly unwished for, utterly undesired, utterly disagreeable,â€™ it is of hell that, rightly speaking, this should be said, so much so that it is hard to find a simile for the suffering in hell.â€

When this was said, a bhikkhu asked the Blessed One: â€œBut, venerable sir, can a simile be given?â€

8. â€œIt can, bhikkhu,â€ the Blessed One said.1199 â€œBhikkhus, suppose men caught a robber culprit and presented him to the king, saying: â€˜Sire, here is a robber culprit. Order what punishment you will for him.â€™ Then the king said: â€˜Go and strike this man in the morning with a hundred spears.â€™ And they struck him in the morning with a hundred spears. Then at noon the king asked: â€˜How is that man?â€™â€”â€˜Sire, he is still alive.â€™ Then the king said: â€˜Go and strike that man at noon with a hundred spears.â€™ And they struck him at noon with a hundred spears. Then in the evening the king asked: â€˜How is that man?â€™â€”â€˜Sire, he is still alive.â€™ Then the king said: â€˜Go and strike that man in the evening with a hundred spears.â€™ And they struck him in the evening with a hundred spears. \[166\] What do you think, bhikkhus? Would that man experience pain and grief because of being struck with the three hundred spears?â€

Â 

â€œVenerable sir, that man would experience pain and grief because of being struck with even one spear, let alone three hundred.â€

Â 

9. Then, taking a small stone the size of his hand, the Blessed One addressed the bhikkhus thus: â€œWhat do you think, bhikkhus? Which is the greater, this small stone that I have taken, the size of my hand, or Himalaya, the king of mountains?â€

â€œVenerable sir, the small stone that the Blessed One has taken, the size of his hand, does not count beside Himalaya, the king of mountains; it is not even a fraction, there is no comparison.â€

â€œSo too, bhikkhus, the pain and grief that the man would experience because of being struck with the three hundred spears does not count beside the suffering of hell; it is not even a fraction, there is no comparison.

Â 

10. â€œNow the wardens of hell torture him with the fivefold transfixing. Â 

11. â€œNext the wardens of hell throw him down and pare him with axes. There he feels painful, racking, piercing feelings. Yet he does not die so long as that evil action has not exhausted its result.

Â 

12. â€œNext the wardens of hell set him with his feet up and his head down and pare him with adzes. There he feels painful, racking, piercing feelings. Yet he does not die so long as that evil action has not exhausted its result.

Â 

13. â€œNext the wardens of hell harness him to a chariot and drive him back and forth across ground that is burning, blazing, and glowing. \[167\] There he feels painful, racking, piercing feelings. Yet he does not die so long as that evil action has not exhausted its result.

Â 

14. â€œNext the wardens of hell make him climb up and down a great mound of coals that are burning, blazing, and glowing. There he feels painful, racking, piercing feelings. Yet he does not die so long as that evil action has not exhausted its result.

Â 

15. â€œNext the wardens of hell take him feet up and head down and plunge him into a red-hot metal cauldron that is burning, blazing, and glowing. He is cooked there in a swirl of froth. 16. â€œNext the wardens of hell throw him into the Great Hell. Now as to that Great Hell, bhikkhus:

17. â€œBhikkhus, I could tell you in many ways about hell.1200 So much so that it is hard to finish describing the suffering in hell.

## **\(THE ANIMAL KINGDOM\)**

Â 

18. â€œBhikkhus, there are animals that feed on grass. They eat by cropping fresh or dried grass with their teeth. And what animals feed on grass? Horses, cattle, donkeys, goats, and deer, and any other such animals. A fool who formerly delighted in tastes here and did evil actions here, on the dissolution of the body, after death, reappears in the company of animals that feed on grass.

Â 

19. â€œThere are animals that feed on dung. Fowls, pigs, dogs, and jackals, and any other such animals. 20. â€œThere are animals that are born, age, and die in darkness. And what animals are born, age, and die in darkness? Moths, maggots, and earthworms, and any other such animals. 21. â€œThere are animals that are born, age, and die in water. And what animals are born, age, and die in water? Fish, turtles, and crocodiles, and any other such animals. 22. â€œThere are animals that are born, age, and die in filth. And what animals are born, age, and die in filth? 23. â€œBhikkhus, I could tell you in many ways about the animal kingdom, so much so that it is hard to finish describing the suffering in the animal kingdom.

24. â€œSuppose a man threw into the sea a yoke with one hole in it, and the east wind carried it to the west, and the west wind carried it to the east, and the north wind carried it to the south, and the south wind carried it to the north. â€œBhikkhus, the blind turtle would sooner put his neck into that yoke with a single hole in it than a fool, once gone to perdition, would take to regain the human state, I say. Why is that? 26. â€œBhikkhus, suppose a gambler at the very first unlucky throw loses his child and his wife and all his property and furthermore goes into bondage himself, yet an unlucky throw such as that is negligible; it is a far more unlucky throw when a fool who misconducts himself in body, speech, and mind, on the dissolution of the body, after death, reappears in a state of deprivation, in an unhappy destination, in perdition, even in hell. ## **\(THE WISE MAN\)**

Â 

27. â€œBhikkhus, there are these three characteristics of a wise man, signs of a wise man, attributes of a wise man. What three? Â 

29. â€œAgain, when a robber culprit is caught, a wise man sees kings having many kinds of torture inflicted on him*...* \(*as in Â§4*\)...Then the wise man thinks thus: â€˜Because of such evil actions as those, when a robber culprit is caught, kings have many kinds of tortures inflicted on him. Â 

30. â€œAgain, when a wise man is on his chair or on his bed or resting on the ground, then the good actions that he did in the pastâ€”his good bodily, verbal, and mental conductâ€”cover him, overspread him, and envelop him. Â 

31. â€œA wise man who has given himself over to good conduct of body, speech, and mind, \[172\] on the dissolution of the body, after death, reappears in a happy destination, even in heaven.

## **\(HEAVEN\)**

Â 

32. â€œWere it rightly speaking to be said of anything: â€˜That is utterly wished for, utterly desired, utterly agreeable,â€™ it is of heaven that, rightly speaking, this should be said, so much so that it is hard to finish describing the happiness of heaven.â€

When this was said, a bhikkhu asked the Blessed One: â€œBut, venerable sir, can a simile be given?â€

33. â€œIt can, bhikkhu,â€ the Blessed One said. â€œBhikkhus, suppose that a Wheel-turning Monarch1203 possessed the seven treasures and the four kinds of success, and because of that experienced pleasure and joy.

34. â€œWhat are the seven treasures? 35. â€œThen the head-anointed noble king rises from his seat, and taking a water vessel in his left hand, he sprinkles the wheel-treasure with his right hand, saying: â€˜Turn forward, good wheel-treasure; triumph, good wheel-treasure\!â€™ Then the wheel-treasure turns forward rolling in the eastern direction and the Wheel-turning Monarch follows it with his four-constituent army. â€œThen the wheel-treasure plunges into the eastern ocean and emerges again. â€œNow when the wheel-treasure has triumphed over the earth to the oceanâ€™s edge, it returns to the royal capital and remains as if fixed on its axle at the gate of the Wheel-turning Monarchâ€™s inner palace, as an adornment to the gate of his inner palace. 42. â€œWhat are the four kinds of success? Here a Wheel-turning Monarch is handsome, comely, and graceful, possessing the supreme beauty of complexion, and he surpasses other human beings in that respect. This is the first kind of success that a Wheel-turning Monarch possesses.

10. â€œBut here, student, some man or woman is not of an angry and irritable character; even when criticised a lot, he is not offended, does not become angry, hostile, and resentful, and does not display anger, hate, and bitterness. Â

Â 

12. â€œBut here, student, some man or woman is not envious, one who does not envy, resent, and begrudge the gains, honour, respect, reverence, salutations, and veneration received by others. 14. â€œBut here, student, some man or woman gives foodâ€¦and lamps to recluses or brahmins. Â 

16. â€œBut here, student, some man or woman is not obstinate and arrogant; he pays homage to one who should receive homage, rises up for one in whose presence he should rise up, offers a seat to one who deserves a seat, makes way for one for whom he should make way, and honours, respects, reveres, and venerates one who should be honoured, respected, revered, and venerated. 19. â€œThus, student, the way that leads to short life makes people short-lived, the way that leads to long life makes people long-lived; the way that leads to sickliness makes people sickly, the way that leads to health makes people healthy; the way that leads to ugliness makes people ugly, the way that leads to beauty makes people beautiful; the way that leads to being uninfluential makes people uninfluential, the way that leads to being influential makes people influential; the way that leads to poverty makes people poor, the way that leads to wealth makes people wealthy; the way that leads to low birth makes people low-born, the way that leads to high birth makes people high-born; the way that leads to stupidity makes people stupid, the way that leads to wisdom makes people wise.

When one says: â€˜All those engaged in the pursuit of the enjoyment of one whose pleasure is linked to sensual desiresâ€”lowâ€¦and unbeneficialâ€”are beset by suffering, vexation, despair, and fever, and they have entered upon the wrong way,â€™ one thus disparages some. â€œWhen one says: â€˜All those engaged in the pursuit of self-mortificationâ€”painful, ignoble, and unbeneficialâ€”\[232\] are beset by suffering, vexation, despair, and fever, and they have entered upon the wrong way,â€™ one thus disparages some. 8. â€œAnd how, bhikkhus, does there come to be neither extolling nor disparaging but teaching only the Dhamma? Â 

â€œWhen one does not say: â€˜All those engaged in the pursuit of self-mortificationâ€¦have entered upon the wrong way,â€™ but says instead: â€˜The pursuit is a state beset by suffering, vexation, despair, and fever, and it is the wrong way,â€™ then one teaches only the Dhamma. Â 

â€œWhen one does not say: â€˜All those who have not abandoned the fetter of beingâ€¦have entered upon the wrong way,â€™ \[233\] but says instead: â€˜As long as the fetter of being is unabandoned, being too is unabandoned,â€™ then one teaches only the Dhamma. â€œSo it was with reference to this that it was said: â€˜One should know what it is to extol and what it is to disparage, and knowing both, one should neither extol nor disparage but should teach only the Dhamma.â€™

Â 

9. â€œâ€˜One should know how to define pleasure, and knowing that, one should pursue pleasure within oneself.â€™ So it was said. And with reference to what was this said?

Â 

â€œBhikkhus, there are these five cords of sensual pleasure. What five? Forms cognizable by the eyeâ€¦sounds cognizable by the earâ€¦odours cognizable by the noseâ€¦flavours cognizable by the tongueâ€¦tangibles cognizable by the body that are wished for, desired, agreeable, and likeable, connected with sensual desire and provocative of lust. â€œHere, bhikkhus, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unwholesome states, a bhikkhu enters upon and abides in the first jhaÌ„naâ€¦the second jhaÌ„naâ€¦the third jhaÌ„naâ€¦ the fourth jhaÌ„na. 10. â€œâ€˜One should not utter covert speech, and one should not utter overt sharp speech.â€™ So it was said. And with reference to what was this said?

â€œHere, bhikkhus, when one knows covert speech to be untrue, incorrect, and unbeneficial, one should on no account utter it. â€œHere, bhikkhus, when one knows overt sharp speech to be untrue, incorrect, and unbeneficial, one should on no account utter it. â€œSo it was with reference to this that it was said: â€˜One should not utter covert speech, and one should not utter overt sharp speech.â€™

Â 

11. â€œâ€˜One should speak unhurriedly, not hurriedly.â€™ So it was said. And with reference to what was this said?

Â 

â€œHere, bhikkhus, when one speaks hurriedly, oneâ€™s body grows tired and oneâ€™s mind becomes excited, oneâ€™s voice is strained and oneâ€™s throat becomes hoarse, and the speech of one who speaks hurriedly is indistinct and hard to understand.

â€œHere, bhikkhus, when one speaks unhurriedly, oneâ€™s body does not grow tired nor does oneâ€™s mind become excited, oneâ€™s voice is not strained nor does oneâ€™s throat become hoarse, and the speech of one who speaks unhurriedly is distinct and easy to understand.

â€œSo it was with reference to this that it was said: â€˜One should speak unhurriedly, not hurriedly.â€™

12. â€œâ€˜One should not insist on local language, and one should not override normal usage.â€™ So it was said. And with reference to what was this said?

13. â€œHere, bhikkhus, the pursuit of the enjoyment of one whose pleasure is linked to sensual desiresâ€”lowâ€¦and unbeneficialâ€”is a state beset by suffering, vexation, despair, and fever, and it is the wrong way. Therefore this is a state with conflict.

â€œHere, bhikkhus, the Middle Way discovered by the TathaÌ„gata avoids both these extremes; giving vision, giving knowledge, it leads to peace, to direct knowledge, to enlightenment, to NibbaÌ„na. 13. â€œHow, bhikkhu, does one not neglect wisdom?1272 There are these six elements: the earth element, the water element, the fire element, the air element, the space element, and the consciousness element.

14. â€œWhat, bhikkhu, is the earth element? The earth element may be either internal or external. What is the internal earth element? 15. â€œWhat, bhikkhu, is the water element? The water element may be either \[241\] internal or external. What is the internal water element? 19. â€œThen there remains only consciousness, purified and bright.1273 What does one cognize with that consciousness? 25. â€œTherefore a bhikkhu possessing \[this wisdom\] possesses the supreme foundation of wisdom. For this, bhikkhu, is the supreme noble wisdom, namely, the knowledge of the destruction of all suffering.1283

10. â€œAnd what, friends, is the noble truth of suffering? Birth is suffering; ageing is suffering; death is suffering; sorrow, lamentation, pain, grief, and despair are suffering; not to obtain what one wants is suffering; in short, the five aggregates affected by clinging are suffering.

11. â€œAnd what, friends, is birth?1290 The birth of beings into the various orders of beings, their coming to birth, precipitation \[in a womb\], generation, the manifestation of the aggregates, obtaining the bases for contactâ€”this is called birth.

â€œThis is called the noble truth of the way leading to the cessation of suffering.

## **\(THE UNDERLYING TENDENCIES\)**

28. \(i\) â€œBhikkhus, dependent on the eye and forms,1335 eye-consciousness arises; the meeting of the three is contact; with contact as condition there arises \[a feeling\] felt as pleasant or painful or neither-painful-nor-pleasant. 2 MA explains that the Buddha delivered this sutta to dispel the conceit that had arisen in five hundred bhikkhus on account of their erudition and intellectual mastery of the Buddhaâ€™s teachings. 3 *SabbadhammamuÌ„lapariyaÌ„ya*. MÌ£ explains that the word â€œallâ€ \(*sabba*\) is being used here in the restricted sense of the â€œall of personal identityâ€ \(*sakkÌ„yasabba*\), that is, with reference to all states or phenomena \(*dhammÌ„*\) comprised within the five aggregates affected by clinging \(see MN 28.4\). Supramundane statesâ€”the paths, fruits, and NibbaÌ„naâ€”are excluded. The â€œroot of all thingsâ€â€”that is, the special condition that maintains the continuity of the process of repeated existenceâ€”MÌ£ explains to be craving, conceit, and views \(which are the underlying springs of â€œconceivingâ€\), and these in turn are underlaid by ignorance, suggested in the sutta by the phrase â€œhe has not fully understood it.â€

4 The â€œuntaught ordinary personâ€ \(*assutavÌ„ puthujjana*\) is the common worldling, who possesses neither learning nor spiritual accomplishment in the Dhamma of the noble ones, and allows himself to be dominated by the multitude of defilements and wrong views. See Bodhi, *Discourse on the Root of Existence*, pp. 40â€“46.

Â 

5 *PatÌ£havimÌ‡ patÌ£havito saÃ±jaÌ„naÌ„ti*. Although perceiving â€œearth as earthâ€ seems to suggest seeing the object as it really is, the aim of Buddhist insight meditation, the context makes it clear that the ordinary personâ€™s perception of â€œearth as earthâ€ already introduces a slight distortion of the object, a distortion that will be blown up into full-fledged misinterpretation when the cognitive process enters the phase of â€œconceiving.â€ MA explains that the ordinary person seizes upon the conventional expression â€œit is earth,â€ and applying this to the object, perceives it through a â€œperversion of perceptionâ€ \(*saÃ±Ã±Ì„vipallÌ„sa*\). The latter is a technical expression explained as perceiving the impermanent as permanent, the painful as pleasurable, what is not self as self, and what is foul as beautiful \(AN 4:49/ii.52\). Ã‘m reads the ablative suffix *-to* of the Pali as signifying derivation and translates the phrase: â€œFrom earth he has a percept of earth.â€

6 The Pali verb â€œconceivesâ€ \(*maÃ±Ã±ati*\), from the root *man*, â€œto think,â€ is often used in the Pali suttas to mean distortional thinkingâ€”thought that ascribes to its object characteristics and a significance derived not from the object itself, but from oneâ€™s own subjective imaginings. The cognitive distortion introduced by conceiving consists, in brief, in the intrusion of the egocentric perspective into the experience already slightly distorted by spontaneous perception. According to the commentaries, the activity of conceiving is governed by three defilements, which account for the different ways it comes to manifestationâ€”craving \(*tanÌ£hÌ„* \) , conceit \(*mÌ„na* \), and views \(*diÌ£Ì£hi*\).
MA paraphrases this text thus: â€œHaving perceived earth with a perverted perception, the ordinary person afterwards conceives itâ€”construes or discriminates itâ€”through the gross proliferating tendencies \(*papaÃ±ca*\) of craving, conceit, and views, which are here called â€˜conceivings. â€™â€¦He apprehends it in diverse ways contrary \[to reality\].â€

The four ways of conceiving \(*maÃ±Ã±anÌ„*\): The Buddha shows that the conceiving of any object may occur in any of four ways, expressed by the text as a fourfold linguistic pattern: accusative, locative, ablative, and appropriative. The primary significance of this modal patternâ€”enigmatic in the Pali as wellâ€”seems to be ontological. I take the pattern to represent the diverse ways in which the ordinary person attempts to give positive being to his imagined sense of egohood by positing,below the threshold of reflection, a relationship between himself as the subject of cognition and the perceived phenomenon as its object. According to the fourfold pattern given, this relationship may be one either of direct identification \(â€œhe conceives Xâ€\), or of inherence \(â€œhe conceives in Xâ€\), or of contrast or derivation \(â€œhe conceives from Xâ€\), or of simple appropriation \(â€œhe conceives X to be â€˜mineâ€™â€\).

But care is needed in interpreting these phrases. The Pali does not supply any direct object for the second and third modes, and this suggests that the process at work in conceiving proceeds from a deeper and more general level than that involved in the forming of an explicit view of self, as described for example at MN 2.8 or MN 44.7. The activity of conceiving thus seems to comprise the entire range of subjectively tinged cognition, from the impulses and thoughts in which the sense of personal identity is still inchoate to elaborate intellectual structures in which it has been fully explicated.

Ã‘m, however, understands the implicit object of conceiving to be the percept itself, and accordingly translates: â€œhaving had from earth a percept of earth, he conceives \[that to be\] earth, he conceives \[that to be\] in earth, he conceives \[that to be apart\] from earth,â€ etc.

The fifth phrase, â€œhe delights in X,â€ explicitly connects conceiving with craving, which is elsewhere said to â€œdelight here and there.â€ This, moreover, hints at the danger in the worldlingâ€™s thought processes, since craving is pointed to by the Buddha as the origin of suffering.

MA gives prolific examples illustrating all the different modes of conceiving, and these clearly establish that the intended object of conceiving is the misplaced sense of egoity.

133 This is one of the most important suttas in the Pali Canon, containing the most comprehensive statement of the most direct way to the attainment of the Buddhist goal. The sutta, its commentary, and copious extracts from its difficult but illuminating subcommentary have been presented together in translation by Soma Thera in *The Way of Mindfulness*. 139 The structure of this sutta is fairly simple. Following the preamble, the body of the discourse falls into four parts by way of the four foundations of mindfulness:
> I. *Contemplation of the body*, which comprises fourteen exercises: mindfulness of breathing; contemplation of the four postures; full awareness; attention to foulness; attention to the elements; and nine â€œcharnel ground contemplationsâ€â€”reflection on corpses in different stages of decomposition.

> II. *Contemplation of feeling*, considered one exercise.

> III. *Contemplation of mind*, also one exercise.

> IV. *Contemplation of mind-objects*, which has five subdivisionsâ€”the five hindrances; the five aggregates; the six sense bases; the seven enlightenment factors; and the Four Noble Truths.

Thus the sutta expounds altogether twenty-one exercises in contemplation. Each exercise in turn has two aspects: the basic exercise, explained first, and a supplementary section on insight \(essentially the same for all the exercises\), which indicates how the contemplation is to be developed to deepen understanding of the phenomenon under investigation.

Finally the sutta concludes with a statement of assurance in which the Buddha personally vouches for the effectiveness of the method by declaring the fruits of continuous practice to be either arahantship or non-returning.

Mindfulness is set up at the nostrils or the upper lip, wherever the impact of the breath is felt most distinctly; the length of the breath is noted but not consciously controlled. The complete development of this meditation method is expounded in MN 118. For a collection of texts on this subject, see Bhikkhu Ã‘aÌ„Ëšamoli, *Mindfulness of Breathing*.
